captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

GREG LEVINE: This game has the
ability to truly bring this
car to life.

And that's why I'm so proud to
be part of this partnership.

DAN GREENAWALT: I've had the
fortune to be able to work

with racing games, racing
manufacturers, to work in this

industry for over
a decade now.

And I've really seen the
relationship between game

makers and manufacturers
change.

The manufacturers have really
embraced this idea of new

media, and in many ways the
video games, like ours, are

now in the vanguard of building
relationships between
their brand and new customers.

And in that way, we're
actually going beyond

entertainment, and becoming more
of an editorial group.

So we have to stay totally
true to simulation.
We can't pick sides.

But there is a little bit of
a something we get back.

And that is we're on the cutting
edge of physics.

Being able to work with a truly,
truly cutting edge

manufacturer like McLaren
is really exciting.

Their designs are beautiful,
but more than anything, the

physics, the engineering behind
a car like this, behind
their F1 car, it's amazing.

And we're able to learn from
their engineers and

incorporate that into
our simulation.

We can also just
get test data--

I mean, more test data than you
can imagine-- to then test

the physics of our game, and
make sure that we have all of

the variables working
correctly.

GREG LEVINE: To be on the cover
of "Forza" was also a
great opportunity.
But I had one condition.
It had to be authentic.

We had to work closely
with the team.

We had to combine their
engineering expertise with our
engineering expertise.

Although completely different,
we had that same common DNA,
to be the best.
Attention to detail.

To be obsessive and to deliver
an outstanding product.

McLaren is all about
innovation.
It's about pushing the limits.

It's about going the
road less traveled.
It's about pioneering.

And this car really encompasses
everything that we

stand for, everything
we've ever done.

The power, the performance,
the downforce.
This is a true supercar.

DAN GREENAWALT: A big part of
"Forza" is building that
relationship with brands.
Because gamers dream.

They dream about getting
in cars like this.

And this partnership with
McLaren has allowed us to

bring our fans' dreams
to life.

One lucky fan gets to do a
ride-along in the McLaren P1.

GREG LEVINE: When it comes
to once in a lifetime

experiences, riding up the
hill at Goodwood is
truly one of those.

And I'm so glad to say that
McLaren, in conjunction with

"Forza," are offering this
unique opportunity to a lucky

fan somewhere out there
in the world.

All that fan needs to do is go
onto our Facebook page and

register their interest, and one
of those lucky individuals

will be flown to the UK and
taken down to Goodwood, and

they will ride up the hill
in the fantastic P1.

JUSTIN BELL: The original F1,
the three-seater with my dad
at Le Mans--

it was Harrods-sponsored, and
we led for 12 hours and only

just lost the race with
two hours to go.
Another McLaren won.
But it was amazing.

So I've had this sort
of passion for
the brand ever since.
And you see this here--

I think that's what McLaren
are doing that is so good.

Because young people are turning
away, generally, the

statistics say, from
the world of cars.

Driving is becoming
a very-- it's just
functional for people.

So that's why we need to keep
coming up with cars that

inspire people and motivate
them and make them dream.

DAN GREENAWALT: Simulation
is actually an endeavor.

It's more than just something
you achieve.

You're trying to accomplish
simulation.

And the only way to do that is
to be always questioning.
What assumptions do I have?

Do I have all the variables
captured?
And so we're always improving.

Improving the tires,
improving the
suspension, to make it better.
You're never done.

GREG LEVINE: This
is the future.

Gaming is a business that's
growing, it's developing.

And the amazing thing
about gaming--

it gives the opportunities for
fans to experience things they

won't necessarily be
able to experience.

All that's left for me to say
is good luck, and I hope to
see you in Goodwood.

title: McLaren P1 North American Debut, Forza 5, E3 2013 - Presented by McLaren Automotive

comments.text:
I wasn't trying to insult you, dude, I was talking about real target 
audience marks for racing videogames. Chill, not everyone on the internet's 
taking a moment of their day to make you feel bad. iRacing does help 
prepare you though. Not everyone lives in the first world and can afford to 
go to a track whenever they see fit. A lot of world-class drivers spend 
hours in iRacing honing their skills. They believe in it. Just offering an 
overview on an alternative platform. Some people like choice.

iRacing doesn't prepare you for the real thing, practicing using a real

for a lesser audience. This is a Forza video promoting Forza not iRacing so

comments.text: I dont get you, i always play with a controller and turn all assists off.
comments.author: rasqo ramirez

comments.text:
I agree with you! I AM thinking years in the past but here's the kicker - 
so are the publishers. I agree that the team behind Forza 5 has the means 
and the brains to develop all that and make it work perfectly. But then you 
know what happens? The CEO's 12 year old son plays the game and says 'It's 
too difficult'. Done, that's all it takes and Turn 10 will be pressured 
into toning down the realism considerably. It has happened before, but I'm 
with you - I hope they stay true to their vision!
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
The courses are laser scanned - not modelled. It takes up to weeks and an 
entire crew full of high-tech equipment deployed at the tracks to SCAN 
every INCH of it. They don't go there to 'get a feel for the atmosphere', 
they're not given layouts and rough notes about bumps here and there. Where 
you drive on iRacing is where you'll drive in reality. Not important for 
kids who love Lambos, invaluable for people getting real track experience 
while preparing for a real life race.
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
Just check the list of drivers that use iRacing every week. Not juniors or 
people starting into racing - some of them, if I'm not mistaken, have 
multiple world championships under their belt.
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
I'm getting a wheel next month. Hoping for a used G27, and then I'm gonna 
jump right back into it x3
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
I agree with you. Especially when it comes to racing games, publishers have 
a huge track record of all-promise-no-deliver. If you remember how 
aggressively they were marketing Test Drive Unlimited 2 you'll know what I 
mean. Game got released and the driving physics were worst than it's 
predecessor. It was bad enough that I just couldn't play it. Bought the 
game, gave it a chance for like a week and then just gave up. Driving-wise 
TDU2 was developped for 5 year olds with a joystick.
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
I think they lack the money to back up speedy/on-time development. It was 
like that with the graphics (which are still barely managing to catch up to 
PS3 visuals) and it'll probably be a while before they have another 'surge' 
of changes. It's also worth noting that unlike games, which sell in 
different installments, iRacing has to be smooth with their 
additions/tweaks since it is just one continuous virtual experience.
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
Yes it does, and I DO believe EVENTUALLY we will have Gran Turismo and 
maybe Forza reaching a level of 'physics' realism that equals iRacing, 
probably at the same time that iRacing will be reaching a level of visual 
fidelity to rival the consoles. If you ignore the target audiences it is 
basically the same concept (delivering a realistic racing experience) 
approached from two opposing ends - consoles, for obvious reasons, favor 
form over function. Computer simulations do the opposite.
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
I've seen a couple of interviews with.. I believe was the lead programmer 
for iRacing. It was a while ago. I remember a couple of other similar 
simulation services were investing heavily on tire physics as well, it 
seems like that became a trend in the simracing industry. The bottom line 
is iRacing is developed from the ground up for professional training and a 
real racing experience. Console games have the means to achieve that, but 
end up simplified to favor a wider target audience.
comments.author: TheAusup

comments.text:
Remember the GP-series? This was one of the best Sims back then not because 
of the physics, but because G. Crammond made some things unrealistic on 
purpose considering you are in front of a screen and so simply building 
100% on physics won't give you a realistic feel automatically. Those so 
called "hardcore" Sims just deliver a Physics Sim, Forza and GT deliver a 
Simulation-Game. And I wouldn't even sign that the physics are much better, 
Forza Tire sim is better than anything out there right now

comments.text:
McLaren would've had to have worked with a world class simulation system 
(such as iRacing) and have had the car completely 3D scanned (as opposed to 
modelled). As cool and realistic as Forza and GranTurismo look, they're 
still just toys in terms of properly simulating physics and the behaviour 
and interrelation of movable parts in the real world. The amount of time 
spent programming the entirety of physics in Forza doesn't even come close 
to the time developing tire physics alone for iRacing.

comments.text:
I don't know about international, but you didn't hear about Skylines in the

comments.author: roush26

comments.text:
Poll results seem predictable, but I wonder if people would actually sim 
race distance, especially if they knew victory was unlikely. Anyway, 
sanctioning bodies and manufacturers can learn about car enthusiasts from 
gaming. Motorsport is a celebration of cars and speed. Some competitors and 
manufacturers will always take winning too seriously, but the celebration 
concept must prevail in rulebooks, marketing, and financial models.
comments.author: Aaron P

comments.author: JabariWalker20

comments.text:
"but say <1% effectively =0%, hence "NO" 16 yo buy Ferrari or Porsche is 
logically wrong" Like I said, learn some statistics. <<1% is considered a 
'null result'. There is no statistical significance. It literally 
translates 'no consequence'. Not only is <<1% effectively 0, the ONLY 
allowable option is to consider it 0. Better luck next time.
comments.author: Authur Jackson
